container-title: in whose honour Giovanni Battista Pamphilj took his Papal name (Chiomenti Vassalli 1979, 22–23; Freiherr von Pastor 1940, 23). It was under Innocent X that Sant’ Agnese’s cult was renewed when, in the Holy Year of 1650
note: a large altar was erected in front of the old church for Easter celebrations (Studio Forme n.d., 12; Sciubba and Sabatini 1962, 25).
title: The Pamphilj had a particular devotion for Sant’ Agnese, having lived in Piazza Navona since 1470 when Antonio Pamphilj arrived from Gubbio and became tax agent (procuratore fiscale) to Innocent VIII (reigned 1484–92

note: What finally resulted was a combination 9. Innocent X, Pontifex Optimus Maximus, and the church of Sant’ Agnese 191
title: In 1651 plans for a new church to be integrated into the Pamphilj complex were begun. The commission saw several changes of architects. Initial ideas were sought from Giambattista Mola
Further plans were provided by Girolamo Rainaldi
the architect at work on Palazzo Pamphilj and by his son, Carlo
However, both architects were eventually replaced by Francesco Borromini
who modified the preceding designs in order to create a façade that was less rigid than that of the Rainaldi
